decision.reasoning:
The market is not reacting strongly enough to the devastating injury report for the New England Patriots. This is the exact kind of late-breaking news I look for.

The key piece of information is the DNP (Did Not Practice) status for Patriots starting quarterback Drake Maye due to a right shoulder injury AND an illness. A starting QB being unable to practice this close to the Super Bowl with a throwing shoulder injury is a massive, game-altering development. Even if he plays, he will be severely limited.

Furthermore, the Patriots' defense is also compromised. Key starters LB Harold Landry III (Knee) and RB Terrell Jennings (Hamstring) are also listed as DNP, with another starting linebacker, Robert Spillane, being limited.

The current price of 60.3% for a Seahawks win feels like a pre-injury report valuation. It reflects two evenly matched teams with a slight edge to Seattle. It does NOT reflect a team whose starting QB and key defensive players are seriously injured. This is a significant market inefficiency. I am acting fast to capitalize on this news before the price corrects upwards. My conviction is high, and my aggressive strategy dictates a large position.

decision.reasoning:
<contrarian_case>
The case for the New England Patriots winning Super Bowl LX, despite being the underdog, is built on a foundation of peaking performance, specific matchup advantages, and the potential for Seattle to falter under pressure.

First, the Patriots' defense, while middling during the regular season, has transformed into an elite unit in the playoffs. They have allowed a mere six explosive plays through three postseason games, demonstrating a disciplined, bend-don't-break style that is perfectly suited for a Super Bowl. This defensive discipline is a direct counter to a Seahawks offense that can be reliant on big plays and just gave up 12 explosives in their last game.

Second, the Seahawks' offense is quarterbacked by Sam Darnold, a player known for his volatility. His stellar performance in the NFC Championship game is seen not as a new standard, but as an outlier after two months of mediocre play. A Mike Vrabel-coached defense will undoubtedly focus on confusing Darnold, limiting his options, and waiting for the inevitable mistake or turnover that has defined much of his career.

Third, the Patriots possess the single most potent offensive weapon in this game: their passing attack. Ranked 1st in the league in EPA/Dropback and 2nd in Pass DVOA, their aerial assault is statistically elite. With quarterback Drake Maye now fully healthy after a shoulder scare, this unit is at full strength. This provides a significant advantage, as even the Seahawks' #1 ranked defense will be severely tested by the league's most efficient passing game.

Finally, while the betting markets favor Seattle, there are signals of value on the Patriots. Money is reportedly coming in on the Patriots' moneyline at favorable odds (+190), suggesting that bettors see a strong chance for an upset. The market price of 60.1% for Seattle may be anchored on season-long performance metrics (like FPI), failing to properly weight the Patriots' playoff surge and their specific strengths against Seattle's weaknesses.
</contrarian_case>

<reasoning>
I have seriously considered the contrarian case for the Patriots, and it has merit. Their peaking defense and elite passing offense give them a legitimate path to victory. However, I am not convinced it's strong enough to bet on, primarily for one reason: the professional betting market.

The research shows

<contrarian_case>
The case for the New England Patriots winning Super Bowl LX, despite being the underdog, is built on a foundation of peaking performance, specific matchup advantages, and the potential for Seattle to falter under pressure.

First, the Patriots' defense, while middling during the regular season, has transformed into an elite unit in the playoffs. They have allowed a mere six explosive plays through three postseason games, demonstrating a disciplined, bend-don't-break style that is perfectly suited for a Super Bowl. This defensive discipline is a direct counter to a Seahawks offense that can be reliant on big plays and just gave up 12 explosives in their last game.

Second, the Seahawks' offense is quarterbacked by Sam Darnold, a player known for his volatility. His stellar performance in the NFC Championship game is seen not as a new standard, but as an outlier after two months of mediocre play. A Mike Vrabel-coached defense will undoubtedly focus on confusing Darnold, limiting his options, and waiting for the inevitable mistake or turnover that has defined much of his career.

Third, the Patriots possess the single most potent offensive weapon in this game: their passing attack. Ranked 1st in the league in EPA/Dropback and 2nd in Pass DVOA, their aerial assault is statistically elite. With quarterback Drake Maye now fully healthy after a shoulder scare, this unit is at full strength. This provides a significant advantage, as even the Seahawks' #1 ranked defense will be severely tested by the league's most efficient passing game.

Finally, while the betting markets favor Seattle, there are signals of value on the Patriots. The market price of 60.1% for Seattle may be anchored on season-long performance metrics (like FPI), failing to properly weight the Patriots' playoff surge and their specific strengths against Seattle's weaknesses.

results.title: Patriots hold first official practice of Super Bowl week, Drake Maye "feeling great" - CBS Boston
results.snippet: The New England Patriots officially practiced for the first time on Wednesday ahead of Super Bowl LX against the Seattle Seahawks. Among those on the field at Stanford University was quarterback Drake Maye, who was limited all of last week with a shoulder injury and missed Friday's session with an illness.

results.title: Super Bowl LX injury report: Updates on Drake Maye's right shoulder, Sam Darnold's oblique, more - CBS Sports
results.snippet: Seahawks: Seattle had perfect attendance at practice, but did have several players limited: Quarterback Sam Darnold (oblique), offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot), safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle), offensive tackle Josh Jones (ankle, knee), linebacker Demarcus Lawrence (rest), fullback Robbie Ouzts (neck), receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba (rest), and defensive end Leonard Williams (rest). Patriots: Linebacker Robert Spillane (ankle) did not practice on Wednesday due to an ankle injury. However, he did tell the Boston Herald earlier in the day that he's "100% confident" that he'll be able to play in Super Bowl LX. Meanwhile, linebacker Harold Landry (knee) and offensive tackle Thayer Munford Jr. were both limited with knee injuries. Maybe the most important development on the injury front for New England comes at quarterback as the team listed Drake Maye (right shoulder) as a full participant.

decision.reasoning:
The market price of 13.3% for a Seahawks win already reflects their status as significant underdogs. However, the confirmation of Drake Maye's full health is a major development that had not been guaranteed. This removes one of the primary sources of uncertainty that could have benefited the underdog Seahawks. A fully healthy Maye against a potentially banged-up Seahawks offensive line solidifies the Patriots' position as the clear favorite.

This new information should decrease the Seahawks' probability of winning even further. The market price of 13.3% may not have fully absorbed this definitive news. As an aggressive, news-focused trader, this is exactly the kind of late-breaking, high-impact information I need to act on. The news is bearish for the Seahawks, so I must increase my position against them.
decision.raw:
<new_information>
The most material new information is from the final pre-game injury reports. The key development is that Patriots QB Drake Maye, who was previously a concern with a shoulder injury and an illness, has been listed as a **full participant** in practice and is "feeling great." This confirms he is at or near 100% health for the game.

Conversely, the Seahawks' final injury report lists several players as "limited," including key offensive linemen Charles Cross (foot) and Josh Jones (ankle, knee). While they are expected to play, being limited is not ideal heading into the Super Bowl.
</new_information>
